text.author: Emily Dickinson
text.title: With a Flower
text.summary1: (human1) In this poem, the narrator tells of hiding inside their flower, which the poem's addressee, unsuspecting, wears, while feeling almost a loneliness for the narrator.
text.summary2: (claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022; postedited) A poem expresses the narrator's desire to secretly be close to their beloved by becoming a corsage worn on their breast and later elicits loneliness when they fades from their vase, with only angels knowing the full truth of these hidden feelings.
text.summary3: (gpt4o) The narrator conceals themselves in a flower worn on another's breast, symbolizing an intimate, unperceived connection that's acknowledged by angels, and evokes a sense of loneliness when the flower fades from a vase, leaving the wearer unknowingly longing for the hidden presence.
text.summary4: (Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) The poem describes a secret sorrow or loss hidden within a person's innocence, worn on their person without realization, and known to angels.
text.summary5: (Qwen2.5-3B-Instruct; postedited) The poem describes hiding within a flower and being worn by an unsuspecting loved one, who has a feeling of loneness.
